stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on Course 11 ('Oily Boily Bay'), focusing on creating and implementing a new platforming mechanic: wind turbines. He modeled the turbines, struggled with and eventually solved a gimbal lock issue to make them rotate correctly, and began integrating them into the level's red coin mission. The stream also featured extensive discussions on his game design philosophy, particularly regarding player options and his critique of Sonic Mania, as well as his thoughts on the YouTube content 'meta'.

development_findings.summary: Kaze encountered and solved a significant gimbal lock issue when trying to rotate a turbine model. The solution required creating a new, pre-rotated 3D model, highlighting a common but frustrating challenge in 3D game development.
development_findings.quote: That is fucked up. That is like the most fucked up game engine ever. I hate Euler angles.

development_findings.summary: A new platforming mechanic, wind turbines that periodically turn on and off to blow the player vertically or horizontally, was designed and implemented for Course 11.
The game's camera was changed based on feedback from community member Lilaa, showing that Kaze is receptive to external feedback on core mechanics.
development_findings.quote: Lilaa was complaining about it and I kind of saw her point.

development_findings.summary: The project is currently at 42.8 MB of its 64 MB ROM size limit while working on Course 11 of 15.

Kaze discussed a difficult past bug that only occurred on real hardware, where a DMA copy to a misaligned stack variable produced invalid values, demonstrating the challenges of console-specific debugging.
Kaze decided against adding a 'super hard final level' with optional checkpoints, as he feels it undermines the difficulty and that no one would choose to turn the checkpoints off.

Kaze showcased Course 1, which features an 'infinite' draw distance, allowing players to see across the entire level. He acknowledged it causes FPS drops to ~20 FPS in worst-case scenarios but deemed it acceptable for non-platforming areas.
Kaze added the ability for cranes to have hooks that the player can grab onto, expanding the platforming possibilities of that object.

context_findings.summary: Kaze theorizes that the current YouTube 'meta' favors content that serves as 'background noise' over deeply engaging videos, a conclusion he reached after his low-effort April Fool's video outperformed his complex technical content.
context_findings.quote: I have the theory that right now Youtube is in the background noise matter. You're not supposed to make engaging videos. You're supposed to make videos that can be listened to while they're in the background. And that is what will get you the views.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses frustration and disappointment with YouTube analytics, as his meme-based April Fool's video garnered significantly more views than technical videos he invested hundreds of hours into.
context_findings.quote: You know what's depressing? Even though that video was an April Fool's joke, it did better than most of my normal videos... No one gives a shit about anything. This revolutionizing N64 programming, less than fucking Grass April Fool's video.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that games are better with fewer, more meaningful options. He is against adding trivial or cosmetic toggles, arguing it dilutes the intended experience and that developers should focus on creating a single, satisfactory version of the game.
context_findings.quote: People are asking for more options than are worth it. Like, they are asking for options on every little detail... Which very clearly should not be an option. Like at that point, just make your own game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze strongly criticizes Sonic Mania's game design, arguing that its reliance on level memorization and unavoidable damage from off-screen threats makes it an unfair and poorly designed game for a modern audience.
context_findings.quote: Sonic will make you make jumps that require 90 millisecond reaction time, which is outside of the possibility of human reaction time. You have to go slow if you want to play Sonic without getting hit and that's literally just fucking boring.

context_findings.summary: At the start of the stream, Kaze mentioned he was in a bad mood because his bike had been stolen.
Kaze will be a speaker at a tech conference in August, giving a talk on reverse engineering and hacking N64 games.
Kaze mentions he has a tennis elbow from lifting weights, for which a doctor recommended cortisol injections and painkillers, which he refused.

biobak.summary: Kaze mentions needing a specific texture from Biobak, referred to as the 'volley just face texture', indicating their collaboration on art assets.
biobak.quote: Right, so I looked into that file back. I don't know if I have the original file for it anymore. I think it's just the texture I have but I'll look again before I forget.

badub.summary: Badub was not mentioned in this stream.

zeina.summary: Zeina was not mentioned in this stream.

key_stories.title: The Turbine and the Gimbal Lock
key_stories.summary: Kaze designed a new wind turbine mechanic but hit a major roadblock with gimbal lock when trying to make it spin horizontally. After a frustrating struggle live on stream, he devised a workaround by creating a pre-rotated 3D model, showcasing his persistence and problem-solving process.
key_stories.challenge: The team needed a new platforming mechanic for the industrial-themed Course 11, and Kaze struggled to implement a horizontal version of his new turbine idea due to engine limitations.
key_stories.process: Kaze brainstormed a turbine mechanic, modeled it, and implemented its physics. When trying to create a horizontal variant, he was blocked by gimbal lock. After expressing significant frustration and trying various rotation properties, he solved it by creating a separate 3D model pre-rotated 90 degrees in Blender.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze created a working and versatile turbine mechanic for both vertical and horizontal movement, which he immediately began integrating into the level's red coin challenges.
key_stories.key_quote: That is fucked up. That is like the most fucked up game engine ever. I hate Euler angles.

key_stories.title: The YouTube Meta vs. Technical Content
key_stories.summary: Kaze expressed frustration that his April Fool's video about 'touching grass' was more successful than his serious technical content. This led to a monologue on the 'YouTube meta,' where he believes 'background noise' videos are rewarded over engaging ones, revealing his conflict between passion projects and popular content.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze grappled with the fact that his low-effort, meme-based April Fool's video vastly outperformed his serious, high-effort technical videos, forcing him to question his content strategy.
key_stories.process: Kaze compared the view counts of his videos on stream, highlighting the huge disparity. This led him to articulate his theory that the 'YouTube meta' now favors 'background noise' content. He then brainstormed new video ideas with his chat, trying to find a middle ground.
key_stories.outcome: While feeling insulted by the analytics, Kaze accepted this reality of content creation. He decided to make the verbose April Fool's video a yearly tradition and continues to contemplate how to balance making popular content with technically interesting videos.
key_stories.key_quote: You know what's depressing? Even though that video was an April Fool's joke, it did better than most of my normal videos... No one gives a shit about anything. This revolutionizing N64 programming, less than fucking Grass April Fool's video.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned he is scheduled to be a speaker at a tech conference in August. His talk will be about reverse engineering and hacking N64 games.
questions: What was the story behind you getting invited to speak at a professional tech conference?
How do you feel about presenting your hobbyist work in that kind of formal setting?
What is the main message or takeaway you want the audience to get from your talk on N64 hacking?
How does preparing for a formal presentation differ from your process of making a YouTube video?

open_questions.context: Kaze went on a lengthy rant against adding too many minor player options in games, arguing it's better to deliver a single, well-designed, and satisfactory experience.
questions: Your philosophy is strongly against trivial player options. Where does this conviction come from?
Can you share any past experiences, perhaps from other projects, that solidified this view on game design?
How do you draw the line between an essential accessibility option and a feature that just dilutes the game's core vision?
When you receive community feedback asking for more options, what's your internal process for deciding whether to implement it or not?

open_questions.context: Kaze seemed conflicted about the difficulty of the game's final level. He wants to create a very challenging 'fuck you' level but is concerned about frustrating more casual players who want to achieve 100% completion.
questions: You're torn on the final level's difficulty. What is your ideal vision for a challenging final stage in a Mario 64 hack?
How do you plan to balance that vision with the goal of making 100% completion achievable without extreme frustration?
What have you learned from player feedback on the difficulty of your previous games, like 'Last Impact' or 'SM64 Online'?
Have you considered solutions other than optional checkpoints, like the 'buffer' of extra stars you mentioned, to solve this problem?

open_questions.context: Community member Lilaa was mentioned as giving crucial feedback that led to a change in the game's camera, and she also gave live feedback on model artwork during the stream.
questions: Lilaa seems to have a significant impact on the game's polish. Could you describe her role and how she became a key contributor to testing?
What makes her feedback particularly valuable to you?
Can you recall another specific instance where Lilaa's feedback led to a major improvement or change in the game?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned needing a specific texture from Biobak, calling it the 'volley just face texture' and noting it's 'like a famous texture by this point'.
questions: What is the story behind the 'volley just face texture' and why has it become an inside joke or 'famous' among the team?
Can you describe the collaborative process with Biobak for creating and implementing textures for the game?
